The Paradise
9pm, BBC1

Continuing the adaptation of Zola's novel now set in "England's first department store", and the staff are still trying to win the admiration of their Wonka-like employer John Moray. A tougher sale is the show's odd tone of period social realism and unmoored fantasy. This week Sam reveals that behind his sales floor patter lurks a ladies' man, while Denise tries to generate publicity for the store with a competition to find a radiant lady to wear one of the shop's promotional flowers: "Miss Paradise Pinks". No one would blame you if you kept the receipt. John Robinson

Ian Hislop's Stiff Upper Lip – An Emotional History Of Britain
9pm, BBC2

Over three episodes Hislop explores Britain's national character, beginning with how we became known for having a "stiff upper lip". Once upon a time, the English (the focus here) were actually known for their displays of emotion – during the 18th century a cult of sensibility made expressive feeling fashionable for men and women. However, there was also the restraining attitude of politeness, which was to pave the way for a more stoic outlook. As usual, Hislop tells his story in a jaunty style, using lively and – at times – unlikely anecdotes. Martin Skegg

Cuckoo
10pm, BBC3

Ken (gigantic stand-up Greg Davies) holds a meeting to set out a few ground rules now that Cuckoo (SNL alumnus Andy Samberg), his new surprise son-in-law, has nestled himself into the family home. Meanwhile, the family gets set for a "welcome home" party for daughter Rachel, where she plans to unveil her tool of a new husband to her friends. Happily, this second episode suggests that there's more legs to this sitcom than merely the mockery of insufferable new age chump-wits, with Davies doing the beleaguered partriarch bit some justice. Ben Arnold

Lillyhammer
10pm, BBC4

When this show aired in Norway it was watched by 1/5 of the entire population. It's not going to get such a huge viewership over here, but it's worth noting that it wasn't just Norwegian national pride at play – this really is something funny and unique. Giovanni is still sticking out like the sorest thumb imaginable: apart from his continual habit of speaking heavily Brooklyn-accented English while all around him speak Norwegian, his attempts at not making any waves have resulted in him getting girlfriend Sigrid pregnant. The Scandinavian medical system proves a foe no wiseguy is prepared to tackle. Phelim O'Neill

House Of Lies
10pm, Sky Atlantic

Based on Martin Kihn's bestseller, House Of Lies is a smart Don Cheadle-starring US comedy drama with hints of Hustle about it. Part-exposé of the dark arts of consultancy, part-Robin Hood vengeance fantasy, it sees Cheadle and his firm of besuited gunslingers concoct scams designed to fleece the 1% whose chicanery plunged America into economic ruin, beginning with fictional megabank Metro Capital. Lots of meta, fourth wall-breaching addresses to camera from Cheadle, if only to explain some of the consultancy terminology. David Stubbs

Wednesday

Welcome To India
9pm, BBC2

One in six people live in India. That's a lot of people. In this new three-part series, we see how the locals are using all their ingenuity "to carve out a home, and build their future", whether by turning their dwellings into a pub (while avoiding eviction by the local council), or by literally transforming dirt into gold: in an eye-popping sequence, a pair of would-be alchemists turn street sweepings into bling, with the addition of nitric acid and mercury. Ali Catterall

Mrs Biggs
9pm, ITV1

Sheridan Smith's charming portrayal of Mrs Ronnie Biggs concludes with Charmian adapting to life as a single mother in Melbourne. But when a family tragedy strikes, she has a rethink about what she's doing with her life. While she and the boys are pining for Ronnie, he's working as a roofer and living the high life in Rio. And when he finds out that one of his Brazilian lovers is pregnant, he realises he may have the right to remain in the country legally. Ronnie becomes nothing short of punchable when long-suffering Charmian flies in for a visit. Hannah Verdier

Best Possible Taste: The Kenny Everett Story
9pm, BBC4

One of the most divisive figures in a truly polarising decade for comedy, Kenny Everett was nevertheless an 80s superstar, his shrill-voiced, button-pushing schtick proving a hit with viewers. He was also, as the cliche goes with comics, a "complex character", and thus worthy of the warts-and-all treatment meted out to the likes of Kenneth Williams. Here Oliver Lansley (Whites) is tasked with channelling Everett's lively spirit, in a bio-drama that shines a light on his closeted homosexuality and battles with the moral decency brigade. Gwilym Mumford

Body Of Proof
9pm, 5USA

Dr Megan Hunt (Dana Delany) is Quincy in killer heels. A former neurosurgeon married to the job, she lost her licence after a car crash numbed her fingers and she killed someone on the operating table. Now she's a fast-talking Philly medical examiner, a genius who doesn't do things by the book, desperate to get back into her estranged daughter's life. Watching Body Of Proof is the TV equivalent of cooking in mittens, all fat-fingered exposition and fumbled cliches. So, not entirely surprisingly, it's also pretty watchable. Ben Arnold

Perception
9pm, Watch

You have to feel sorry for the few crimefighters in US dramas that don't have help from uniquely-skilled eccentric masterminds. Luckily for FBI agent Kate Moretti (Rachael Leigh Cook) she has the option of calling on paranoid schizophrenic professor of neuroscience Dr Daniel Pierce (Eric McCormack). In this debut, Moretti and Pierce investigate the death of a pharmaceutical executive – along with the hallucinations Pierce's subconscious tends to conjure up. It remains to be seen whether the concept remains fresh, but for now file under "entertaining romp". Mark Jones

Thursday

Wartime Farm
8pm, BBC2

It's 1942 and things are tougher than ever for Britain's farmers. Three years of the German blockade have taken their toll and there are shortages of wood, animal feed and fuel. Every scrap of land is turned over to food production – including parks in London – while "Lumber Jills" are deployed by the Women's Timber Corps to fell trees and "Bevin Boys" are sent to coal mines instead of the front. On the farm, Peter converts an ambulance to run on coal gas, while Ruth sets up a food centre for those bombed out of their homes. Martin Skegg

Hunted
9pm, BBC1

Created by X-Files pensmith Frank Spotnitz and produced by the team behind Spooks, big things are expected from Hunted. Luckily, this opening episode doesn't disappoint, hitting the ground running with assassins, hostages and shootouts from the off. Taking place in the world of industrial espionage, Sam Hunter (Melissa George) finds herself back in active service after a botched mission, while trying to uncover just who betrayed her. While we might not see as action-packed a sequence as the opening scene every week, it's safe to say Hunted is far more than just Bourne on a BBC budget. Mark Jones

Homefront
9pm, ITV1

This drama series about the wives left behind as their menfolk serve in Afghanistan continues to show promise, without as yet exploring the politics of the conflict - though aspects are bubbling underneath. This week, Louise is incensed when she receives a photo of her hubby, back on leave, in a clinch with a female squaddie, which he insists has been photoshopped. Meanwhile, Paula and Tasha, mother and wife of the slain Matt, continue to lock horns. David Stubbs

First Presidential Debate
9pm, PBS

Though President Obama may have the edge in recent polls, the 2012 election is still proving tight. Republican candidate Mitt Romney has led a weak campaign, littered with gaffes. Obama will hope to exploit those flaws and no doubt be keen to claim the 47% of Americans that Romney has apparently disowned, but he has to contend with poor job numbers and a struggling economy. The first of three debates took place last night, and is reshown in full here. It focuses on domestic policy, and is held in the swing state of Colorado. Martin Skegg

The Judy Garland Show
9pm, Sky Arts 2

Repeat showings of the screen legend's 1960s variety series co-hosted by comedian Jerry Van Dyke and including an appearance from her then-ingenue daughter Liza Minnelli. Like most US shows of that era, everyone is overly polite and awkward but it's enjoyable for the nostalgia-paddling in the company of legendary performers like Tony Bennett, Ethel Merman and Peggy Lee. And poignant too to see a fortysomething Garland on the downward slope. Tonight she welcomes former co-star Mickey Rooney and they duet up a storm. Julia Raeside

Red Dwarf
9.40pm, Dave

Following the 2009 Back To Earth specials, Rimmer, Lister, Cat and Kryten return for a six-part series of new adventures. If that smacks of trying to reinvigorate a franchise best left back in the 20th century, the first, largely moose-gag powered scenes here may give further cause for concern, being just not funny. Gradually, though, things improve as the boys explore an abandoned ship and comic timing reasserts itself. Patchy, but the idea of Rimmer crashing on account of "self-created malware" powered by his own resentments suggests that some of the old magic may still be there. Jonathan Wright

Friday

Strictly Come Dancing
9pm, BBC1

First episode proper of the 10th season of the show that's seemingly never off telly/Twitter. Once more, Tess and Methuselah will be presiding over the cha-cha-cha, as Len, Bruno, Craig, and a new face - the one and only Darcey Bussell - offer "constructive" criticism during the first of this weekend's two live shows. Would-be hoofers include Victoria Pendleton, Jerry Hall, Johnny Ball and Sid Owen. There's no elimination this week, so they can all rest easy. For now. Ali Catterall

Servants: The True Story Of Life Below the Stairs
9pm, BBC2

"You can't get the help these days" is a phrase which well described the state of domestic service in Edwardian England, where increasing industrial opportunities for the working classes resulted in numbers of those working in service dropping by around 5,000 a year. In the second part of Dr Pamela Cox's exploration of service, she finds that things downstairs were changing. It was the poorest in society who were drafted in to make up numbers, pulled out of the workhouses, taught household skills, and then whisked off into servitude for middle- and upper-class families. Ben Arnold

QI
10pm, BBC2

If there's a winning quality to QI, it's that you can never quite tell who's going to be any good at its blend of wit, recondite knowledge and public house esoterica. It was wonderful, for example, to watch Bill Bailey triumph and Jimmy Carr tank utterly a couple of weeks ago. At times it can seem like a bit of a boys' club, it's true – but tonight comic Sarah Millican continues to hone her mainstream chops, while other contestants include Mr Victoria Coren, David Mitchell, and the former 80s pop star turned broadcasting vicar Rev Richard Coles. John Robinson

Leeds International Piano Competition 2012: Finalists Story
7.30pm, BBC4

This year's contest has been run and won by 24-year-old Italian Federico Colli. This is another chance to hear one of the finalists he defeated, 26-year-old Australian Jayson Gillham. Gillham – who has won several other prizes, including 2011's Brant International Piano Competition and this year's Royal Overseas League Music Competition – performs Beethoven's Piano Concerto No 5 in E-flat major. Also included: a brief history of the grand piano. Suzy Klein presents. Andrew Mueller

Modern Family
8pm, Sky1

First in the fourth season of the madly popular US sitcom. Jay's hoping his birthday will pass without mention but his nightmarish family have other ideas. Ideas to do with fishing, and boats, and potential drowning. And will Gloria choose this happy day to drop her pregnancy bomb on the birthday boy? Meanwhile, Mitchell and Cameron struggle for emotional buoyancy after a failed adoption bid and decide to get a cat. Pity the cat. Julia Raeside

Moone Boy
9.30pm, Sky1

It's confirmation time for Martin Moone, and he has something of an epiphany during the service: he wants to be one of those cool altar boys. Once he's accepted into the gang, he discovers there's nothing sweet and innocent about his priest-terrorising new friends. Martin soon gets to the top of his profession and gets to serve on Holy Thursday, so starts a strict training regime to make sure he's the best altar boy ever. But when his sister Fidelma joins the choir his parents can't help but wonder what they did wrong to make
half their children devout church-goers. Hannah Verdier

In the hallway of Bidzina Ivanishvili's extraordinary glass home is a work by Gilbert & George. It is to Ivanishvili's credit that he agrees to be photographed next to it and a slogan that reads: "SAY FUCK OFF TO RICH BASTARDS." Ivanishvili is, after all, worth $6.4bn (£3.9bn), and one of the richest bastards, or successful businessmen, on the planet.

His possessions include a zoo with penguins, lemurs and a zebra, kept at his village in western Georgia, and a large collection of modern art. There are sculptures by Henry Moore (the art works dotted around his residence are all fake, the originals "kept safe" in a London vault). His home is a striking one-off – a James Bond-like space-age palace of steel and tubular columns, with panoramic views of Georgia's twinkling capital Tbilisi. Aides nickname it the 'glassle'. There is also fleet of black Land Cruisers.

The one thing that Ivanishvili doesn't have is power. Or at least not yet. In October 2011 the Georgian billionaire dramatically and unexpectedly entered politics, challenging the country's president Mikheil Saakashvili in a battle that has become increasingly nasty and personal. Ivanishvili charges that Saakashvili - who swept to power in 2003 during the rose revolution - has morphed into a dictator. On Monday, Georgians vote in a epochal parliamentary election. The choice is between Saakashvili's ruling party and Ivanishvili's anti-government Georgia Dream coalition.

As Ivanishvili tells it, it was Saakashvili's despotic behaviour that forced him into politics. "I'm 56 years old. I decided to go into politics because of our Soviet-style government," he says. The tycoon says that in 2008 Saakashvili "bought" off Georgia's old parliamentary opposition, forcing him to forge a new alliance last year with the country's surviving independent political forces.

In an interview on Sunday evening with several international newspapers including the Guardian, Ivanishvili complains bitterly of the persecution he has endured ever since. The state has stripped him of his Georgian citizenship. Several of his activists have been arrested. He even hints that Saakashvili is personally capable of dark deeds. "I'm very happy that I'm physically alive. We could have experienced pretty much everything from this government," he says, flanked by members of his opposition team.

Despite his loathing for Georgia's president, however, Ivanishvili's policies seem rather similar. On foreign policy, he says this: "Our policy is European and Euro-atlantic integration. There is no substitute for Nato." The pro-western Saakshvili's believes the same: it was his desire to join Nato that contributed to the Kremlin's crushing invasion of Georgia in 2008, following the president's doomed attempt to wrest back breakaway South Ossetia.

Ivanishvili has previously stated that Vladimir Putin's Russia is now freer than Saakashvili's Georgia. Asked about this, Ivanishvili gets irritated; his response surprisingly thin-skinned. The government has painted Ivanishvili as a Russian agent and the accusation clearly grates. He made his fortune in Russia in the 1990s (banking, pharmacy, real estate) but says he has now sold off two-thirds of his Russian assets; he still has a significant chunk of Gazprom. "You journalists are always asking about Russia," he says.

But how might he improve relations with the prickly Putin, the man who promised to hang Georgia's current president "by the balls"? "I think it's important to reinstate cultural and commercial relations," he says. And what about Abkhazia and South Ossetia, the two rebel regions occupied by Russian tanks, and recognised by Moscow as "independent" following the 2008 war? "When it comes to reinstating territorial integrity this will be a very hard and long task. I don't have illusions it will happen easily," he admits.

In the run-up to the election, Transparency International has accused both sides of presenting "simplistic programmes", promising large investments in agriculture, education, healthcare and social benefits. Critics say Ivanishvili's plan is vague, incoherent even. The billionaire says he main priority is jobs; certainly ordinary Georgian voters complain of high unemployment, low pensions and a lack of opportunities. He points out that unlike Saakashvili he understands business.

Western diplomats in Tbilisi fear that if Ivanishvili's coalition loses his supporters will take to the streets, with weeks of turmoil to follow. Ivanishvili, however, says his movement is peaceful. If international observers - currently packing out Tbilisi's al fresco restaurants - certify the election as free and fair he will accept the result; his coalition will form the parliamentary opposition. "Without doubt," he emphasises in English. He's more comfortable, though speaking in Georgian or Russian.

Interview over, we troop out past the Gilbert & George fake, and admire the stunning view from his terrace as the sun sets over a picture postcard Tbilisi. Ivanishvili points to the giant sphere hovering as if in mid-air inside his palace. "It's actually a cafe. You can fit 150 people inside," he says. Behind his residence is Tbilisi's wild botanical garden; Ivanishvili's private quarters resemble an inverted flying saucer about to take off. The billionaire says he's been to London twice but hasn't met Tony Blair or David Cameron.

And what about his zoo? Saakashvili's aides say the penguins are evidence of his eccentricity. Actually, it appears he is genuinely fond of his animals. "I bought my penguins from a zoo in France. I've got four of them," he says. He admits Georgia's warm climate is not really "sustainable" for his pet zebra and says he likes his lemurs. "They're like cats really. But I haven't got a big zoo." As well as his bid to defeat Georgia's president, Ivanishvili has another problem: too many deer. His small herd keeps on breeding, he says. "Would you like to take a deer home?" he asks with a smile.

Voters in Georgia go to the polls on Monday in the most bitter and closely fought election since the pro-western rose revolution swept president Mikheil Saakashvili to power in 2004.

For the first time, Saakashvili's ruling United Movement party faces a serious challenge from an opposition coalition headed by the flamboyant Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili. Both sides claim that independent polls put their parties in front.

The parliamentary election follows an acrimonious campaign in which there have been allegations the government has intimidated and arrested opposition activists. Ivanishvili accuses Saakashvili of turning Georgia into an authoritarian state and on Sunday said Georgia's human rights record was worse than Russia's.

The government has hit back. Officials say the billionaire, who made his fortune in Russia in the 1990s, is a Kremlin stooge attempting to use his vast resources to buy the election. They also say some members of his six-party Georgian Dream coalition are nationalists and Stalinists – a claims Ivanishvili rejects.

Georgia is deeply divided. Most residents in the capital, Tbilisi – where an estimated 100,000 Ivanishvili supporters rallied on Saturday – support the opposition. But Saakashvili enjoys an electoral advantage in rural areas, and among the country's ethnic Armenian and Azeri minorities.

Western diplomats fear a disputed election result could lead to weeks of turmoil and street protests. Some opposition supporters admit they will take action if the Georgian Dream coalition fails to win.

"There will be a revolution. We will take to the streets. We'll fight with our fists," Georgi Gogoladze, an unemployed university graduate in tourism, said on Saturday.

Tamar Chugoshvili, chair of Georgia's young lawyers' association, said discontent with the government was widespread. She said Saakashvili had at first developed the country's economy, and promoted democratic values.

In recent years, however, he had failed both as a democrat and a reformer, she suggested: "At the beginning he did some positive things. But where he really failed was in building institutions, including democratic institutions." She added: "He didn't build parliament as a parliament or a judiciary as a judiciary. Instead, power is concentrated in Georgia in the hands of three or four people who make all the decisions."

Chugoshvili said the election campaign had been a battle not between rival political parties, but between the opposition and the state. The playing field had been "uneven" she suggested, with the media and party financing rules titled in the government's advantage. "The judiciary has acted in favour of the ruling party only," she said.
